pr_title: Fixes #1054: "make unbuilt index readable" exception blocks opening a record store

timeline.message: Fixes #1054: "make unbuilt index readable" exception blocks opening a record store

timeline.body: Hm, it seems like this should probably take a `CompletableFuture<V>` instead of a `Supplier<CompletableFuture<V>>`, which is generally what these methods take, but then I suppose you don't get the behavior that the same handler gets used constructing or executing the future, so I suppose it's probably fine.
timeline.bodyText: Hm, it seems like this should probably take a CompletableFuture<V> instead of a Supplier<CompletableFuture<V>>, which is generally what these methods take, but then I suppose you don't get the behavior that the same handler gets used constructing or executing the future, so I suppose it's probably fine.
timeline.bodyHTML: Hm, it seems like this should probably take a CompletableFuture<V> instead of a Supplier<CompletableFuture<V>>, which is generally what these methods take, but then I suppose you don't get the behavior that the same handler gets used constructing or executing the future, so I suppose it's probably fine.
timeline.author: alecgrieser

timeline.body: ```suggestion * Handle when futureSupplier encounters an exception when supplying a future, or the future is completed ```
timeline.bodyText: Suggested change * Handle when futureSupplier has exception when supplying a future, or the future is completed * Handle when futureSupplier encounters an exception when supplying a future, or the future is completed
timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
* Handle when <code>futureSupplier</code> has exception when supplying a future, or the future is completed
* Handle when <code>futureSupplier</code> encounters an exception when supplying a future, or the future is completed
timeline.author: alecgrieser


timeline.author: alecgrieser

timeline.body:
```suggestion
                                logExceptionAsWarn("unable to build index", exception);
```

It also seems like we might want to include things like the index name as a log key. Maybe `logExceptionAsWarn` should take a `KeyValueLogMessage` (and handle adding the log keys from the exception as well)?
timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
logExceptionAsWarn("unable build index", exception);
logExceptionAsWarn("unable to build index", exception);

It also seems like we might want to include things like the index name as a log key. Maybe logExceptionAsWarn should take a KeyValueLogMessage (and handle adding the log keys from the exception as well)?
timeline.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText:
Added index name to log key.
logExceptionAsWarn already handles adding the log keys from the exception if it's a LoggableException
replies.author: nblintao

timeline.body:
There's something about having this catch and then ignore the error that feels a little strange....

Given that we're going to ignore the results of doing the validation, it almost seems like we should call `uncheckedMarkIndexReadable`. I could see alternative arguments that we could, like, check there are no uniqueness violations or data in the index subspace or something and then mark it as `READABLE` (perhaps only in the error case) (and maybe it also should add the `\x00` to `\xff` range to the build space?).

I could also see an argument that if it encounters an error, it should mark the index as `DISABLED` and wait for a rebuild. Then we don't get the index right away (sad) but we also no longer block `checkVersion`.

Something about the extra flag to force marking it as readable doesn't quite seem right.
timeline.bodyText:
There's something about having this catch and then ignore the error that feels a little strange....
Given that we're going to ignore the results of doing the validation, it almost seems like we should call uncheckedMarkIndexReadable. I could see alternative arguments that we could, like, check there are no uniqueness violations or data in the index subspace or something and then mark it as READABLE (perhaps only in the error case) (and maybe it also should add the \x00 to \xff range to the build space?).
I could also see an argument that if it encounters an error, it should mark the index as DISABLED and wait for a rebuild. Then we don't get the index right away (sad) but we also no longer block checkVersion.
Something about the extra flag to force marking it as readable doesn't quite seem right.
timeline.bodyHTML:
There's something about having this catch and then ignore the error that feels a little strange....

Given that we're going to ignore the results of doing the validation, it almost seems like we should call uncheckedMarkIndexReadable. I could see alternative arguments that we could, like, check there are no uniqueness violations or data in the index subspace or something and then mark it as READABLE (perhaps only in the error case) (and maybe it also should add the \x00 to \xff range to the build space?).

I could also see an argument that if it encounters an error, it should mark the index as DISABLED and wait for a rebuild. Then we don't get the index right away (sad) but we also no longer block checkVersion.

Something about the extra flag to force marking it as readable doesn't quite seem right.
timeline.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText:
I didn't use uncheckedMarkIndexReadable mainly because I'd like it check and log exceptions even if not throw an exception.
I think " mark the index as DISABLED and wait for a (manual, force) rebuild" is an option. I just need to remove all my changes in markIndexReadable it will work like that. But that depends on how we see such error. If we think consider it as expected (even though not pleasant) as a side effect of reusing index name, I think it should better be working without manual intervention.
replies.author: nblintao

replies.bodyText: Force build is not necessary. Just manual. So I think I'm fine with not marking index as readable, especially considering there may be underlying bugs that we need to be aware of.
replies.author: nblintao
